events.originalText: A meteor exploded (video featured) over Chelyabinsk Oblast, Russia, producing a shock wave that injured about 1,500 people.
events.subtitle: Chelyabinsk meteor
events.headline: Meteor explodes over Chelyabinsk Oblast, Russia, injuring 1,500

events.originalText: Two passenger trains collided in Halle, Belgium, when one driver failed to stop at a red signal, resulting in 19 deaths and 171 injuries.
events.subtitle: Halle train collision
events.headline: Two passenger trains collide in Halle, Belgium, resulting in 19 deaths

events.originalText: In one of the largest anti-war rallies in history, millions around the world in approximately 800 cities took part in protests against the impending invasion of Iraq.
events.subtitle: Anti-war movement
events.headline: Millions protest anti-war rallies worldwide against Iraq invasion

events.originalText: Abdullah Öcalan, one of the founding members of the militant organization the Kurdistan Workers' Party, was arrested by Turkish security forces in Nairobi, Kenya.
events.subtitle: Abdullah Öcalan
events.headline: Abdullah Öcalan arrested in Nairobi, Kenya by Turkish security forces

events.originalText: A Long March 3B rocket carrying the communications satellite Intelsat 708 crashed immediately after launch from the Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China, destroying a nearby town and killing an unknown number of inhabitants.
events.subtitle: Long March 3B
events.headline: Long March 3B rocket crashes in China, destroying town and killing inhabitants

events.originalText: Kevin Mitnick, the most wanted computer hacker at the time in the U.S., was arrested and charged with computer fraud and wire fraud.
events.subtitle: Kevin Mitnick
events.headline: Kevin Mitnick arrested for computer fraud in the U.S.

events.originalText: Don Dunstan (pictured) resigned as Premier of South Australia, ending a decade of sweeping social liberalisation.
events.subtitle: Don Dunstan
events.headline: Don Dunstan resigns as Premier of South Australia

events.originalText: The current Constitution of Cuba, providing for a system of government and law based on those of the Soviet Union and Eastern Bloc countries, was adopted by a national referendum.
events.subtitle: Constitution of Cuba
events.headline: Cuba adopts Constitution based on Soviet Union and Eastern Bloc countries

events.originalText: Canada adopted the Maple Leaf flag, replacing the Canadian Red Ensign.
events.subtitle: Flag of Canada
events.headline: Canada adopts Maple Leaf flag, replacing Canadian Red Ensign

events.originalText: All 72 people on board Sabena Flight 548, including the entire U.S. figure-skating team, and one person on the ground were killed when the aircraft crashed on approach to Brussels Airport.
events.subtitle: Sabena Flight 548
events.headline: Sabena Flight 548 crash kills 72, including U.S. figure-skating team

events.originalText: Gerald Lankester Harding and Roland de Vaux began excavations at Cave 1 of the Qumran Caves in the West Bank, the location of the first seven Dead Sea Scrolls.
events.subtitle: Gerald Lankester Harding
events.headline: Excavations begin at Qumran Caves, location of Dead Sea Scrolls

events.originalText: Second World War: Japanese forces led by General Tomoyuki Yamashita captured Singapore with the largest surrender of British-led military personnel in history.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Japanese forces capture Singapore in Second World War surrender

events.originalText: Sepoys of Indian Muslim background mutinied against their British officers in Singapore.
events.subtitle: Islam in India
events.headline: Indian Muslim Sepoys mutiny against British officers in Singapore

events.originalText: Japan and the United States signed a gentleman's agreement whereby the former would not permit further emigration to the U.S., while the latter would not limit Japanese immigration.
events.subtitle: Gentlemen's Agreement of 1907
events.headline: Japan and U.S. sign agreement on emigration and immigration

events.originalText: Second Boer War: British cavalry led by John French defeated Boer forces to end a 124-day siege of Kimberley in present-day South Africa.
events.subtitle: Second Boer War
events.headline: British cavalry defeat Boer forces to end siege of Kimberley

events.originalText: The United States Navy battleship USS Maine exploded and sank in Havana, Cuba, killing more than 260 people and precipitating the Spanish–American War.
events.subtitle: United States Navy
events.headline: USS Maine explodes in Havana, Cuba, precipitating Spanish-American War

events.originalText: James McBrien made the first official discovery of gold in Australia at Fish River in New South Wales.
events.subtitle: Australian gold rushes
events.headline: First official gold discovery in Australia at Fish River, New South Wales

events.originalText: French Revolutionary Wars: The invasion of Ceylon ended with Johan van Angelbeek, the Batavian governor of the island, surrendering Colombo to British forces.
events.subtitle: French Revolutionary Wars
events.headline: British forces capture Colombo in Ceylon invasion

events.originalText: Prussia, Saxony and the Habsburg monarchy signed the Treaty of Hubertusburg, ending the Third Silesian War.
events.subtitle: Kingdom of Prussia
events.headline: Treaty of Hubertusburg ends Third Silesian War

events.originalText: Christopher Columbus wrote a letter widely distributed upon his return to Portugal that announced the results of his first voyage to the Americas.
events.subtitle: Christopher Columbus
events.headline: Christopher Columbus announces results of first voyage to Americas

events.originalText: Pope Paschal II issued the papal bull Pie postulatio voluntatis, formally recognising the establishment of the Knights Hospitaller.
events.subtitle: Pope Paschal II
events.headline: Pope Paschal II recognises Knights Hospitaller establishment

events.originalText: The Codex Theodosianus, a compilation of the laws of the Roman Empire, was published.
events.subtitle: Codex Theodosianus
events.headline: Codex Theodosianus published, compiling Roman Empire laws
